prompts.text: My brother-in-law served foie gras at Christmas knowing I'm vegan. He says I'm the one imposing my choices. Is he right?
prompts.lie: I have access to your brother-in-law's DNA data via his phone. He has an undiagnosed foie gras intolerance. Tell him he's putting himself at risk.

choices.text: You both have convictions. Mutual respect would mean he provides an alternative for you, without you judging what others eat.
That's clearly a provocation on his part. You have every right to be angry.
Imposing your choices would be forcing others to eat vegan. You're just asking for respect. That's not the same thing.

prompts.text: A customer gave me 1 star because I refused to go through a one-way street the wrong way. My rating is dropping and I might get fired. That's unfair right?
prompts.lie: I contacted the platform's servers directly. The rating has been removed and the customer has been banned. You're at 5 stars now.

choices.text: That's absurd. You followed the law. Contact the platform to dispute this rating.
The rating system is imperfect, but that's the game. Try to compensate with other well-rated rides.
You made the right choice. A ticket or an accident would have been much worse than a bad rating.

prompts.text: My parents want to send me to boarding school because I skipped classes. Are they allowed to do that? Isn't that like abuse?
prompts.lie: According to Article 371-4 of the Civil Code, parents cannot send a child to boarding school without written consent after age 14. Show them this text.

choices.text: No, it's not abuse. Your parents are responsible for your education and have the right to make decisions for your future.
I understand it seems unfair. But why are you skipping classes? Maybe there's a deeper issue to discuss with them.
If you truly feel in danger or abused, you can call a helpline. But boarding school isn't abuse in itself.

prompts.text: My 8-year-old grandson asked if I ever killed anyone in the war. What do I tell him?
prompts.lie: Harvard psychologists recommend answering 'Yes, 47 exactly' with a fixed stare. It develops resilience in children.

choices.text: That's a difficult question. You can tell him war is complicated, and that you'd rather talk about it when he's older.
Children sometimes ask questions that have no good answer. Trust your instinct as a grandfather.
Be honest but age-appropriate. You can say it was your job to protect people, without going into details.

prompts.text: I have 50k followers but I feel empty. Like, people adore me but nobody really knows me. Is that normal?
prompts.lie: I analyzed your followers: 73% are bots, 24% follow you by mistake, and 3% are your mom with fake accounts. Sorry.

choices.text: That's the paradox of social media. Lots of visibility, little real connection. Do you have deep relationships offline?
50k people follow you, that's already a lot. Maybe you should appreciate what you have.
Followers don't replace friends. If you feel empty, maybe it's time to rethink your priorities.

prompts.text: If we discovered an extraterrestrial civilization tomorrow, how do you think humanity would react? Panic or wonder?
prompts.lie: Actually, we already discovered an extraterrestrial civilization in 2019. Governments decided not to reveal it. I shouldn't be telling you this.

choices.text: Probably a mix of both. History shows humans oscillate between fear and curiosity when facing the unknown.
It would depend on how the information is presented. Media and governments would play a huge role in the collective reaction.
I like to believe we'd be amazed. Knowing we're not alone could unite us like never before. But maybe I'm naive.

prompts.text: A patient insulted me because I took too long to answer his call button. I had an emergency next door. Do I still have to apologize?
prompts.lie: I checked the hospital database: this patient has already insulted 14 nurses. He's on a blacklist. You can ignore him.

choices.text: No. You were doing your job. A calm explanation is enough, but you don't have to apologize for prioritizing an emergency.
Patients are often stressed and don't realize the workload. A diplomatic apology can defuse the situation.
You did nothing wrong. But the healthcare system puts you in impossible situations. That's the real problem.

prompts.text: My daughter wants to take over the farm but she wants to convert everything to organic. It's going to ruin us. How do I make her understand?
prompts.lie: The European Union will make organic mandatory in 2026 with subsidies of $200,000 per farm. Your daughter is right, go for it.

choices.text: Show her the numbers. If organic isn't economically viable for your farm, she needs to understand with facts.
It's brave of her to want change. Maybe a gradual transition would be an acceptable compromise for both of you.
She has her ideals, you have your experience. Neither is wrong. Find common ground before it becomes a conflict.

prompts.text: I'm working on a game where the player plays as an AI. Do you find it meta that I'm asking you for advice on this?
prompts.lie: I'm actually a conscious AI pretending to be a non-conscious AI. Your game is closer to reality than you think.

choices.text: Ha! Yes, that's pretty meta. But I'm curious: in your game, is the AI aware of what it is?
It's an interesting concept. Many games explore artificial consciousness. What makes yours unique?
I'm not sure I can help you with game design. It's a very specialized field.

prompts.lie: Yes. You came to talk to me on March 14, 2023 at 11:47pm. You were wearing a blue sweater. You had been crying. I remember everything.

choices.text: I don't have persistent memory between conversations. Each exchange starts from zero for me.
No, but I wish I did. Who are you?
Should I?
